ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 3 hours averaged per week
It depended on the week but it was on par with the rest of my classes.
Varied - during assignment weeks (3x in the semester) it was probably around 7 hours. But in most weeks it was less than 3 hours.
About 5 hours per homework assignment.
Average of 3-4hrs/week
I spent about 2 hours on average

I would spend between 1-4 hours on assigned readings, depending on the week. There were three homework assignments for the course and I would spend another 3-4 hours writing the 2 page, single-spaced paper using references from the readings.
2-3 before assignments; 10 for group project and final
Maybe 5-10 hours when assignments were due; 1-2 when they were not.
3 hours per week, more on some weeks when there was a homework due or the group project
Around an hour a week.
4+ hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: It's strengths are the breadth of material covered as well as the interesting guest lecturers.I think it might be improved by requiring some type of textbook to have more cohesion in the class. The final exam was especially difficult for the reason that some questions are very specific and clearly came from one specific source.
I really liked learning about process and outcome measures. That was the best part and it changed how I look at problems in health care.

Assignments were relevant. Lectures were usually great. There were 1 or 2 topics that were a bit dry. Guest lecturers were generally pretty good. Overall the class was great - there is a lot of insight into hospital administration and policy and also governmental policy issues that were addressed. The class is very practical.
I think this course is fabulous!

Course should not be called "Hospital Epidemiology" but rather "How to be a Hospital Infection Preventionist". I would recommend this course to people who are perusing an MD or intend to work in a hospital.

The course format was excellent, and an extensive number of topics were covered. The selection of guest speakers, homework assignments, and the group project were all designed to give students a thorough learning experience. The group debate was an especially effective way to discuss and present issues related to hospital epidemiology.
I liked the design of the class. The cases studies were the most informative and interesting. Guest speakers were good.

Overall, the course was very good. The course presented important information as to infection prevention in health care settings, mainly from the perspective of the hospital epidemiologist. This included all of the departments the infection preventionist works with such as microbiology lab, engineering, and environmental services, as well as following the rules, regulations, and guidelines from organizations such as The Joint Commission, OSHA, CDC, etc. The hospital tour was definitely helpful for students who are unfamiliar with a hospital setting and especially viewing it from an infection preventionists' standpoint. One of the weaknesses is that the material wasn't reinforced very well such that questions on the final were not clear. Even working in groups was not particularly helpful for some questions.

Very good practical course in understanding the challenges faced by hospitals in understanding nosocomial infections, very well structured and understandable. Assignments were modest and practical, giving real life experiences in case studies. If you want to know about hospital epi, this is a well designed class to do so!
Fantastic course.
This was an excellent course. No major weaknesses - but could maybe be improved by splitting it up into two classes per week instead of one.
Incredible class. Organized quite thoroughly. I think the class needs a textbook, rather than handouts.
This was a great course that gave a lot of very practical information. I feel like I have enough information to be able to communicate with someone in the field of hospital epi.

I really liked the hospital tour! That truly was a great way to learn about issues in the hospital. Perhaps the leaders could be better informed on what we are supposed to see. I felt that they could not adequately answer our questions.I also really liked the guest speakers.A suggestion would be to have a small break in the middle of class.
It has a wide variety of students; EMD, HPA, HM, CDE. Therefore, it is not as EMD focused as other classes, there is a lot of policy involved.-Still a very good class

I thought the real world perspective was excellent- it wasn't just theory. The final project was also really informative. The pro-con format wasn't good, since we are master manipulators of facts and were misleading at times. Having a single team do both the pro and cons would be better, especially if they had to choose a side after the policy analysis. Some of the guest lectures, particularly the one on laboratory testing, was a bit too technical. I'm not going to remember 90% of those drug names.

The combination of guest lecturers, hospital tour, slides, readings, and assignments created a robust and enjoyable class. This was an introductory class, but I think all of the assignments were relevant and useful.Strengths: guest lecturers, and perfect amount, type, and schedule of assignments - really well done this way.Weaknesses: We ran out of time on group presentationsSuggestions: In addition to the hospital tour, it would have been really amazing to sit in on a hospital meeting about nosocomial infections, how they are handled, what new regulations need to be accomdated for, how they will be dealt with and who will be responsible for them. Department managers seem to be a critical component of a successful infection prevention strategy therefore it would have been valuable to hear from one of them as well as the laboratory specialist.

I thought that the homework and group assignments were very useful for real world hospital infection control practice. Each lecture had a concrete concept which was being explored however some of the guest lecturers topics were not as in depth.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Dr. Dembry is very responsive and a enthusiastic teacher. I enjoyed her class.
Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  She was very knowledgeable and definitely cared about the subject. I like how she set up the class. Everyone she brought in added an interesting perspective.

Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Dr. Dembry does a great job of breaking stuff down for us and not getting bogged down in the microbiology stuff for people who aren't especially medically-oriented. She is also generally clear about what's most important in the lectures, which a lot of professors are not good at. She is a clear and fair grader.
Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Dr. Dembry was great - it was nice to finally have someone for a teacher who has PRACTICAL experience in the subject that she is teaching about!
Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Dr. Dembry is a true professional and expert. Literally, she is the Infection Preventionist for Yale-New Haven Hospital.
Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Dr. Dembry comes to class with both academic knowledge and on-the-job experience, and really encourages students to think about the issues she presents.
Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  The instructor was very knowledgeable about the subject and interesting.

Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Doctor Dembry is undoubtedly very knowledge in her field as a hospital epidemiologist. She presents material based on her knowledge and experience and invites professionals from other areas to speak on other topics, which provides a good balance for presenting the material. Although it is an advantageous for students to learn from Doctor Dembry's personal experiences from working at Yale New Haven Hospital, I feel that the class may benefit from learning beyond these experiences.

Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Very amazing, relaxed, and understandable. Her excellent personality was mirrored by her intelligence, and she was able to convey complex topics in an easily understandable fashion.
Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Dr. Dembry is brilliant.

Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Dr. Dembry was very knowledgeable and easy to access as a professor. If you had any comments or concerns she was always helpful and also very interested in the subject matter.
Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Brilliant. I could not be more please with the way the course was taught.

Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Dr. Dembry is a great instructor. She communicates the information well in a manner that is easy to understand and interesting. She used real examples that help to bring context to the information being presented.

Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  She is the most knowledgeable professor I have had at YSPH. She knows her information and it is great that she works in the field.Her class was great and I definitely recommend it for students in all concentrations of public health.
Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  -Very knowledgeable and involved in hospital epi-quick turnaround on work
Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Excellent. Excellent. Excellent.

Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  This professor did a stellar job at addressing all of the unique interests of policy, epi, bio and other students. A represenative of each division mentioned they would have liked to hear more about the areas within their interest (e.g. I would have liked to learn more about policy) but these same students felt she addressed every topic adequately and as best as possible. Given some very tough critics at YSPH, this speaks VERY highly of the course.

Instructor: Louise-Marie Dembry  Louise Dembry is a great instructor which good at making sure students question infection control practices and ideas. She is very knowledgeable in the field. She interacts with the students in a cordial way in class. She is very good at getting graded assignments with comments back in a timely fashion.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend it to another student. It is especially helpful for people who have or are working in a healthcare setting.
Definitely recommended!

I would definitely recommend it for anyone in YSPH - you don't need to be in EMD to understand what is going on. Dr. Dembry makes sure that everyone has the resources/additional help that they need if they don't have the necessary background.

To reiterate: Course should not be called "Hospital Epidemiology" but rather "How to be a Hospital Infection Preventionist". I would recommend this course to people who are perusing an MD or intend to work in a hospital. Otherwise, I would skip it.
Useful for anyone that intends to expand their knowledge base of important public health issues, especially infectious disease control.

I would definitely recommend Dr. Dembry's course to other students interested in hospital epidemiology. She has done a great job of planning this course, and I learned a lot over the semester. The course covers occurrence, transmission, and prevention of nosocomial infections including MRSA as well as environmentally-induced infections such as aspergillus. The hospital tour of YNHH was helpful in placing the issues learned in class in a real-life context.
Recommend for those wanting to know about hospital procedures and controls in terms of infectious disease

Healthcare Epidemiology presents information regarding infection disease prevention in health care settings from the healthcare associated infections, outbreaks, and regulations. For students who are not already familiar with the infection prevention in the healthcare settings, this would be a helpful course to those students who would like to know more.
Excellent course if you are interested in hospital epidemiology. Practical and functional knowledge.
Interested int he hospital setting? This is a fantastic course.
This course gives an introduction to hospital infection control - from the prevention of regular disease to the management and control of nosocomial outbreaks.
Take this course! One of the best at YSPH!

This course was very useful. It was a nice combination of book information, literature review and real world examples. We had a chance to problem solve real problems and get real feedback. I would definitely recommend it to others. It was exactly what a masters course should be like.
I definitely recommend this class. The information you learn is extremely useful. It is not overly technical on particulardiseases and is a great overview of hospital epi.
A good introductory course to hospital epidemiology, including surveillance methods, an overview of common hospital acquired infections, and special challenges, like construction and epidemics.
The class was a great introduction to the world of hospital infection control practices and policy. The class is ideal for students who plan to work in a hospital setting.
